snippet: In the Town of Southold, a hamlet popular with second-home buyers; properties range from raised ranches to hilltop estates.
abstract: Living In column on Cutchogue, Long Island. Maps, Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: LOUISA HARGRAVE came to Cutchogue in 1973 because she and her husband at the time, Alex, discovered that as the sunniest place in New York State, it is ideal for growing grapes to make wine. They founded Hargrave Vineyard and helped start an industry that has transformed the North Fork of Long Island, which is home today to nearly 50 vineyards and wineries. ''To me, Cutchogue is the heart of the agricultural North Fork,'' said Ms. Hargrave, now a wine consultant and columnist, and a real estate agent. ''People come because of an appreciation for its rural character. I love the water, the sunshine, the farmland and the light. Because of the refraction from the sea, you can get a kind of enchanted light.''
